data.title: 90s Album Thread: The Black Crowes' “Shake Your Money Maker” (1990)
data.meta_description: When my oldest brother turned 16 in the early 80s, I was relegated to the back seat of a White Volkswagen Rabbit every morning to be thrown out of the car at my elementary school as we passed it on…
data.text:
When my oldest brother turned 16 in the early 80s, I was relegated to the back seat of a White Volkswagen Rabbit every morning to be thrown out of the car at my elementary school as we passed it on the way to the high school.

I learned early on that I had no say over what went on the radio. None. I was immersed in my older brother’s taste in music. He’d latched onto what we would nowadays call “Classic Rock,” and he didn’t seem that interested in heading anywhere else. I got a Master’s degree in the Rolling Stones, but I also minored in Alabama, Lynyrd Skynyrd and .38 Special.

By 1990 I was driving myself around with complete control of the radio when something strange came over the airwaves. The song was “Hard to Handle” and was the first single off The Black Crowes’ debut album “Shake Your Money Maker.” It was strange because it was new but sounded kind of old. The tune reminded me of my days in the back seat of the Rabbit, so I wasn’t entirely sure what to make of it. But after releasing the second single, “She Talks to Angels,” I drove to City…
